content:
Diagnosis:		Metastatic pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (islet cell)

Management:		Commenced Lanreotide 120mg q28d March 2024
		Cycle 3 Capecitabine/Temozolomide commenced April 2024

Histology:		Well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumor, Ki67 15%, chromogranin A and synaptophysin positive

Current Situation:	Pre-cycle 4 CAPTEM review

I reviewed [redacted name] today in the neuroendocrine clinic. She is tolerating the combination of Lanreotide and CAPTEM chemotherapy remarkably well. Her initial symptoms of diarrhea and flushing have significantly improved with Lanreotide. The main side effect has been grade 1 hand-foot syndrome from Capecitabine, which she is managing with regular moisturizing. Her most recent CT scan from 15/5/24 shows stable disease in the pancreatic primary (4.2cm) and partial response in the liver metastases with the largest lesion reducing from 3.8cm to 2.9cm. Chromogranin A has decreased from 890 to 450. Performance status remains 1.

The plan is to proceed with cycle 4 CAPTEM today and continue Lanreotide. We will arrange a follow-up CT after cycle 6 to assess response. Next clinic review in 4 weeks with blood tests including chromogranin A, FBC, U&Es, and LFTs.

primary_cancer.biomarker_status: Ki67 15%, chromogranin A and synaptophysin positive

cancer_timeline.value: CT shows stable pancreatic primary (4.2cm) and partial response in liver metastases with largest lesion reducing from 3.8cm to 2.9cm

status_updates.value: Metastatic pancreatic NET showing partial response to combination of Lanreotide and CAPTEM chemotherapy with improving symptoms
Partial response in liver metastases and stable primary tumor on CT, with falling chromogranin A
Proceeding with cycle 4 CAPTEM and continuing Lanreotide
CT scan after cycle 6 to assess response
Review in 4 weeks with blood tests including chromogranin A, FBC, U&Es, and LFTs
